objective: count in hundreds to 1000.
approach:
To begin this lesson, recap the renaming of 10 ones to make 1 ten and 10 tens to make 1 hundred. Provide students with Base 10 materials to show the renaming. Then ask students if they know what 10 hundreds would make. Introduce the number 1000 and write 1000 both in numerals and words. Allow students to have a sense of how big 1000 is by talking about experiences where multiples of hundreds, up to 1000, would be encountered, such as the number of pages in Harry Potter books are in hundreds (e.g. The Order of the Phoenix is about 800 pages, exact: 766); or show them real objects, such as 10 boxes of paper clips with 100 paper clips in each box.
Students should be familiar with a single Base 10 100 'flat' but they will need support when using multiple 'flats' to count in hundreds. Remind students of the value of the digit in the hundreds place and the significance of the zeros in the tens and ones place when reading and writing hundreds.
Show students the Explore task. Count up in hundreds while either pointing at the jars of marbles or using sets of 100 until you get to 1000. Count backwards in hundreds from 1000 to zero. Show the class the pictures in Master and ask them whether they can see any patterns. Students may mention that there is an additional 100 in the following row. Ask them whether there is a link between the numbers on the right-hand side (100, 200, 300, etc.) and the amount of 100-blocks on the left side. Guide students so they can see that 400 has 4 blocks of 1 hundred and 700 has 7 blocks of 1 hundred. Ask them questions on how many hundreds they think other numbers will have and assess their answers. Students have to relate that 1000 will have 10 blocks of 1 hundred, therefore, 10 hundreds can be renamed to make 1 thousand.
During Guided Practice, students are using pictorial support to write numbers in numerals and in words.

approach:

Then count aloud with students, 'three hundred and forty-six' while pointing at the Base 10 materials. Ask them if they know how to write this number. Write 346 and read it aloud again, pointing to the digits one by one. Ask them how many hundreds are there in 346, then how many tens and how many ones. As they answer, ask them how they know.
Ask students if the hundreds, tens and ones in the number 346 could be shown using a number bond. Allow them time to explore how a number bond diagram could be used to represent a 3-digit number. They learnt how to use a number bond to show the tens and ones of a 2-digit number in Year 2.
How could we break apart the number 306? What about 340? Allow students time to work on this and for them to show different ways of deconstructing numbers using a number bond diagram.
During Guided Practice, students are representing numbers using number bond diagrams.

objective: recognise the place value of each digit in a 3-digit number (hundreds, tens, ones).
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Provide them with place-value charts and Base 10 materials. Ask them if they are able to show you the number and explain what the digit 6 stands for. Allow them some time to work on this. As there are 6 10-blocks in the tens place, the digit 6 stands for 6 tens. Write the number 60, and in words, six tens. Do the same for the digits 3 and 2.
Tell the class your friend said they can use a number bond diagram to represent this number. What might that look like? Ask students if they are able to write the number shown using both numerals and words. Read aloud the number 362 as you write it in numerals and read it aloud again when writing it in words, 'three hundred and sixty-two'. Guide students to differentiate between writing the place value of the digits – 3 hundreds, 6 tens and 2 ones (plural form) – and writing the number in words – three hundred (singular form) and sixty-two (without tens and ones). Help them understand that when writing the number in words, we write it in the same way as we read it.
Ask students if they are able to represent the number 470 on the place-value chart and then write a number bond for it. Tell them that your friend said they made 400, 60 and 10 when using a number bond diagram. Is this correct? Are there other ways? Ask students for the place value of each digit in the number and ask them to write the place values, 400, 70 and 0, both in numbers and words. Then read the number aloud together and invite students to write 470 in words as they read it aloud again.
During Guided Practice, students are representing numbers in different ways, using place-value charts and number bond diagrams, and in numerals, words and number sentences.

objective: compare and order numbers up to 1000.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and ask them to tell you which child has more stickers. How can we figure this out? How do we know? How many ways are there to find out which child has more? Students must first determine the number each child has, Sam has 253 and Lucy has 326. Then ask them to write the numbers on a place-value chart. What do we know about the hundreds in each number? Which number has more hundreds? Does this matter? Why? Guide students to see that hundreds are greater than tens and ones, and tens are greater than ones, so if one number has more hundreds, it must be greater than the other other number. Therefore, 326 is greater than 253.
Show this to students using both manipulatives and a place-value chart. Ask them what happens when they have the same number of hundreds. What if we wanted to compare 764 and 758? Allow students time to make these numbers. Ask them how many hundreds, tens and ones they both have. Guide students to generalise that if the hundreds are the same, then we can compare the tens, and if both the hundreds and tens are the same, then we proceed to compare the ones.
Get students to discuss which number has the greatest number of hundreds, tens and ones, and then complete a quick survey to determine which number is the greatest. Allow a student to explain why they think 764 is bigger than 758 by demonstrating to the class using manipulatives. Ask students how they can compare three numbers. What should we look at first? Which place in a number has the greatest value; which has the least?
During Guided Practice, students are comparing numbers using Base 10 materials, place-value cards and then ordering numbers from smallest to greatest and vice versa. students will also be using the symbols <, > and = to compare numbers.

objective: count from 0 in multiples of 50.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and ask them how many ways they can think of to count the total number of harakeke in the picture. Allow them to work with concrete materials to do this. After some time, tell them your friend said that counting in fifties is easy: 50, 500, 5000, 50 000, 500 000 and so on. Is this correct? How do we know? Allow students to discuss this and come up with a rebuttal. Allow them to discuss what the 5 in 50 represents. Ask them how many fifties we need to make 100, 500, 1000.
Explain that today's lesson will be on counting in fifties or, to make things more exciting, the '50 times table'! Ask students whether they notice any patterns when counting the harakeke (in bundles of 50). Some may say they go up in fifties, some may say there is always a 100 or 50 at the end of each number. Ask students why they think that for every two fifties we go up by 100. You want them to see the link that 2 fifties make 100, so we should move up 100 every time we add 2 fifties. You also want students to generalise and see that counting up in fifties is similar to counting up in fives in that there will either be a 50 at the end of the number or a multiple of 100. Prompt them to realise that 9 fifties is just 1 less 50 than 10 fifties. Use this as a strategy to show relational patterns. Ask students questions such as, 'If 6 fifties makes 300, how many will 5 fifties give us?', 'If 4 fifties gives us 200, how many will 2 fifties give us?' Ensure students have an opportunity to say the fifties in words, for example, 250 is read as two hundred and fifty.
During Guided Practice, students are making the link between counting in fives and counting in fifties. They will use both pictures and number tracks/number lines to do this.

objective: find 10 more or less than a given number using number patterns.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and ask them if they are able to tell you the missing numbers from the pattern. More importantly, ask them to show you how they know. Allow them to use Base 10 materials, number lines, drawings and so on to show their reasoning. Tell them your friend said that they created a special number pattern: 314, 324, 334. What comes next? How do we know? Can we show what we know?
It is important during this lesson that students don't race to the answer but focus more deeply on recognising and describing the patterns. Guide them to recognise the number patterns using number lines and Base 10 materials. Help them to describe patterns using '1 more' and '10 more' than the previous number and to see that a number pattern can also be '1 less' or '10 less'. Allow students time to work with one another to create number patterns that are 1 more/1 less and 10 more/10 less.
During Guided Practice, students are finding numbers by 1 more/less and 10 more/less. They are also completing number patterns and sequences. Ask students if they can make a link between the diagram in Guided Practice 1 and a 100-square. What happens to numbers in a vertical direction? What happens to numbers in a horizontal direction?

approach:

What is the place value of the digits that change? Is there a rule they can come up with?

objective: count in fours and eights.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Lay out pencils or similar manipulatives in the arrangement shown. Ask students what they notice about the layout. Some pencils are grouped in tens and the others are grouped in what looks like fours, but this may not be very clear to everyone. Ask students how we can find the total number of pencils. Encourage them to show you the different strategies, such as counting all, and counting in tens then ones. Get students to count to 100 in tens and then count in fours for the rest of the pencils. As they count in fours, start writing the numbers on the board: 104, 108, 112, 116. Altogether, there are 116 pencils.
Then show students that, as 8 is the double of four, we can also count in eights. Group the pencils in eights and count together with students while writing the numbers on the board: 108, 116. Altogether, there are 116 pencils. Guide students to compare the two lists of numbers and ask them if they can see any patterns. They should notice that 108 and 116 appear in both lists. Help them to conclude that counting in eights is the same as doubling counting in fours.
During Guided Practice, students are counting in fours and eights.

objective: understand the commutative law of addition and form a family of addition and subtraction facts.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Use it to stimulate discussions relating to commutative law. Ask students to find the total number of poi for 11 red poi and 5 black poi and to write an equation for the solution (11 + 5 = 16). Ask them whether the solution would be the same if there were 5 black poi and 11 red poi. Would the equation be the same? (5 + 11 = 16) Guide students to see that both equations will give us the same answer. Try this with other sets of 2 numbers (e.g. 8 black poi and 7 red poi), and then 3 numbers (e.g. 4 red poi, 5 black poi and 6 blue poi). Help students conclude that when we add, the order of the numbers does not affect the answer.
Then ask students, now that we know the total, what can we do to find the number of black poi? Will the equation be the same? Can we use the same numbers to make a subtraction equation? (16 – 5 = 11) What if we want to find the number of red poi? What does the equation look like? (16 – 11 = 5) Guide them to see that with the same 3 numbers, we can form a family of addition and subtraction facts.
During Guided Practice, students are completing families of addition and subtraction facts.

objective: add two 3-digit numbers without renaming, using the column method of addition.
approach:
Students learnt the column method of addition in Year 3. In this lesson, help them to apply this knowledge to adding 3-digit numbers. Use this lesson to make sure any misconceptions are eradicated, especially for struggling learners.
To begin this lesson, show the class the Explore task. Ask some students to demonstrate how the number 413 could be shown in terms of hundreds, tens and ones using Base 10 materials. Do the same for 582. Ask the class where we should begin when we want to add 582 to 413. Get them to add the ones, tens and then hundreds. Ask students if they can represent this addition using the column method. Give them time to write the column method and help struggling students to recall how to do this. Then ask students to explain why the addition always starts from adding the ones. Guide them to relate addition to the renaming from ones to tens to hundreds.
During Master, emphasise the importance of placing digits with the same place value together when adding using the column method. Use Base 10 materials alongside the column method to better illustrate this.
During Guided Practice, the emphasis is on the column method.

objective: add a 3-digit number to ones with renaming.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and ask them to discuss with their partners how they could add 7 to 345. Allow them to use Base 10 materials to get to the answer. Then ask them to share their answers and gather their methods. Show the class all the methods as illustrated in the textbook.
Method 1 is a bridging process using the expanded column method. It helps students to see the renaming process and understand that the column method essentially adds by renaming. This can be used for struggling learners who are not yet ready to move to the standard column method.
Method 2 is the standard column method. Use Base 10 materials as well as number bonds alongside the column method to make the method explicit. Compare the similarities between methods 1 and 2 so students can see the link between them.
Method 3 uses knowledge of number bonds to make the next ten, and then add the remainder of the ones. It is important to go through all the three methods so that students gain an understanding of the question and numbers, rather than just following a procedure.
During Guided Practice, provide students with digit cards to form the addition statements.

objective: add a 3-digit number to multiples of 10 with renaming.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Ask the students what they think will change when the numbers are added to each score. What do they notice about the tens place? Discuss the methods from previous lessons that could be used to find a solution to the problem. Agree that the addition statements are 593 + 50, 695 + 70 and 498 + 50.
Show Lulu's addition statement: 593 + 50. Ask students, when using Base 10 materials and a place-value chart, what happens to the tens when there are more than 9 tens. Along with the Base 10 materials, show the expanded column method and help students link the column method to the concrete representation. Repeat this using Tama's example: 695 + 70.
After going through these two examples (593 + 50 and 695 + 70), ask students to add the same numbers using the standard column method. Then ask them to add 498 and 50 using a number bond.
After practising addition using all the three methods, ask students to compare the 3 numbers – 593, 695 and 498. Guide them to use approximation: 593 is about 600, 695 is about 700 and 498 is about 500; then compare 600, 700 and 500. It will be much easier to see which number is greatest or smallest using this method. Help them to see that a 3-digit number with 9 tens is very close to the next hundred. Students can check the calculations using a calculator to evaluate their approximations.
During Guided Practice, students are performing a similar task to the Explore activity, with specific criteria around how to use the numbers.

objective: understand and learn the 3 times table.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and ask them how many ways they can count the number of muffins. Allow them some time to come up with all the ways they can think of to do this. Go through the different methods they suggest. Remember that all answers are appropriate here, e.g. counting all, counting on from 3 and using a number line.
If no one suggests using multiplication to solve the problem, guide students to see that the muffins are grouped into 3 on each tray. How could this be helpful? We can count in threes. Then count together with students. We can also say that there are 5 groups of 3, which gives us 15. Write the equation 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 + 3 = 15 then write the equation 5 × 3 = 15. Highlight the efficiency of multiplication over addition in this instance. Ask students what are 4 groups of 3, 3 groups of 3, 2 groups of 3 and 1 group of 3. Write down each equation and help students relate the times table to 'groups of'. During Master, encourage students to commit the 3 times table to memory. Ask the students why there are no cubes above the zero in Master 3? objective: recall and use the 3 times table.
approach:
This lesson uses patterns in the 3 times table to help students commit the 3 times table to memory easily.
To begin this lesson, show students the picture from the Explore task and ask them how the snapper are arranged. They are arranged in 4 rows of 3, therefore, we write it as 4 × 3 = 12. Explain that 4 × 3 means 4 rows of 3. Ask students how they would work out 5 × 3 if we know 4 × 3 = 12. Draw another row of 3 snappers beneath the first 4 rows. Now we have 5 rows of 3, which can be written as 5 × 3 = 15. Support students by explaining that 5 × 3 means 1 more row of 3, so if we know 4 × 3 = 12, then 5 × 3 is 12 plus another row of 3, which is 15. This will help students see that in the 3 times table, the next number is always 3 more than the previous one. Therefore, if they know 5 × 3 = 15, they can find 6 × 3 by adding 3 to 15.
The other strategy students can learn is the doubling of groups. If 1 group of 3 is 1 × 3 = 3, then 2 groups of 3 will be 3 + 3 = 6. What is 4 groups of 3? Help students to see that 4 is double of 2, so if 2 × 3 is 6, then 4 × 3 is the same as 6 + 6 = 12. Guide them to realise that this strategy applies to all the times tables.
During Guided Practice, students are practising the two strategies and completing a number sequence for the 3 times table.

objective: recall and use the 4 times table.
approach:
This lesson uses patterns in the 4 times table to help students commit the 4 times table to memory easily.
To begin this lesson, show students the picture from the Explore task and ask them how the paua shells are arranged. They are arranged in 5 rows of 4, therefore, we can write it down as 5 × 4 = 20. Ask students what 5 × 4 means. They should be able to apply their knowledge from the previous lesson that it means '5 groups of 4'.
Ask students how they would work out 4 × 4 if we know 5 × 4 = 40? Delete a row of 4 paua shells. Now we have 4 rows of 4, which can be written as 4 × 4 = 16. 4 × 4 is one row fewer than 5 × 4, so if we know that 5 × 4 is 20, 4 × 4 will be 4 less than 20, so 20 – 4 = 16. This will help students see that in the 4 times table, the previous number is always 4 less. Therefore, if they know 5 × 4 = 20, they can find 4 × 4 by subtracting 4 from 20. Guide students to realise that this strategy applies to all times tables.
The other strategy is the doubling of groups, which students learnt in the previous lesson. If 2 groups of 4 is 2 × 4 = 8, ask students what are 4 groups of 4 and 8 groups of 4.

objective: recognise the pattern in the 4 and 8 times tables.
approach:
This lesson looks at the links between multiplying by 4 and by 8. The class has already looked at multiplying by 4 in the previous two lessons and therefore they are familiar with the numbers that appear in the 4 times table.
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Ask them to think of different ways to work out how many slices of cheese there are altogether. Tell students your friend said that the 4 and 8 times tables are connected. What do they mean? Use the pictures to encourage students to explain that for every 2 fours we make an eight. So 2 groups of 4, (2 × 4) is the same as 1 group of 8, (1 × 8); 4 groups of 4, (4 × 4) is the same as 2 groups of 8, (2 × 8). Ask students if they can show you other examples from the 4 and 8 times tables.
Ask students to write the 4 times table and the 8 times table, side by side. Ask them if they can see any patterns. Guide them to see that the 8 times table is double the 4 times table, for example, 2 × 4 = 8 and 2 × 8 = 8 + 8 = 16. This will help students to see the patterns in the 4 and 8 times tables. So if they know the 4 times table, they just need to double it for the 8 times table. The diagrams used in Master 1, pictorially represent doubles. Students should read these as doubles and understand the relationship between the 4 and the 8 times tables.
Move on to ask students to show you a diagram or a picture that represents 6 × 8. You are looking for students to draw 6 rows of 8 (dots or any other items). Ask them what the answer is. Ask students how zero groups of 8 could be shown in Master 1? How would you write this? Introduce the term 'product' and explain that the word 'product' means the answer when multiplying two or more numbers together. So we can say that the product of 6 and 8 is 48.
During Guided Practice, students are using their knowledge of the times tables and applying the strategies learnt to answer the questions. Students are given an opportunity to find the product of two numbers.

approach:

objective: solve word problems involving multiplication.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and discuss the problem with them. What key information is given? 17 cars in the car park and twice as many cars parked on the road. What is the problem asking us to find? The number of cars parked on the road; the total number of parked cars. Allow them some time to work on this.
Can we represent the problem using bar models? Begin moving students in this direction through questioning, giving them time to work it out for themselves. Only use questioning when students are unable to move forward on their own. How can we draw the bars to represent the cars? Which one should be larger? Use coloured paper or card to represent the bar for the cars in the car park. How large should we make the bar for the cars parked on the road? Having the same sized bar for both colours means we have the same amount, so we need the road bar to be bigger.
The problem says there are twice as many cars parked on the road as there are in the car park, so we need to have two bars which are each the same size as one car park bar. What value does the car park bar represent? So how can we work out the value of the road bar? It is twice as big as the car park bar: 17 × 2. How can we multiply 17 by 2? (10 × 2) + (7 × 2). Therefore, the number of cars on the road is 20 + 14 = 34.
What calculation do we need to do to work out how many cars are parked altogether? There are 17 cars parked in the car park and 34 cars parked on the road. So we can add the amount of parked cars together to find the total. 17 + 34 will give us the total number of parked cars. Work through Master 2 in the same way.

approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Ask them to discuss how they can know for certain which one of the items is the heaviest and which one is the lightest. How do we know which item is the heaviest and which item is the lightest? 100 is the biggest number; is the box of biscuits heavier than the bag of rice or the bag of potatoes? Do we know how many grams make a kilogram? 1 kg = 1000 g, so the rice weighs 2000 g. How many grams does the bag of potatoes weigh? We have three items with the masses of 100 g, 2000 g and 4000 g. We can say that the box of biscuits is the lightest and the bag of potatoes is the heaviest. Remind students they need to read the numbers and the units of measurement. They need to be aware that they are comparing grams and kilograms.

To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Ask them how much they think the pumpkin weighs. Can they answer the question in kilograms and grams? What about just in grams? Give the students time to explore.
Let the class know that there is one pupil who thinks the pumpkin weighs 1 kg 30 g and another who says it weighs 1 kg 300 g. Who is correct? Ask them how they can be sure. Show students Master. Count from zero and point at the markings to show that each marking must be 100 g and not 10 g as we know 1000 g gives us 1 kg.
During Guided Practice, students are reading scales in kilograms and grams.

objective: read weighing scales to determine mass in kilograms.
approach:
To begin this lesson, remind students that we have been looking at mass and how to measure the mass of an item using a weighing scale for the past three lessons. Ask them whether or not all weighing scales have the same scale. Show students weighing scales (or use pictures of weighing scales) with different scales and guide them to look at the number of intervals to differentiate them.
Show students the Explore task and allow them to discuss what the mass of the bag of onions could be. Gather their thoughts and discuss the scale. Is it the same as the last Explore task?
Show Master 1; the picture of five 200 g weights on the scales. If five 200 g weights weigh 1 kg, where do they think the needle would be if we only had one 200 g weight? What about two, three and four? What does this tell us about each of the small markings?
Go through the other items in Master (the the bag of pears and the cake) to see if the class can read the scale to determine the mass of each item, then come back to the bag of onions. How much does the bag of onions weigh?
During Guided Practice, students are determining the masses of items in grams and kilograms.

objective: solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of mass.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and discuss the problem with them. Guide students to see that this is a part–whole scenario as the bowl and the apples together will make the whole. Students will first have to determine the mass of the whole by reading the weighing scale, which is about 800 g. If the apples on their own weigh 535 g, can you work out how much the bowl weighs?
Gather suggested solutions from the class and discuss the bar model that can be drawn for this problem as in Master. The whole bar is 800 g and one part (the apples) weigh 535 g. How can we work out what the bowl weighs? We can count on from 535 until we get to 800 g, but a faster way is to subtract 535 g from 800 g.
Encourage students to think about the mass of items they are familiar with. For example, a book has a mass of about 350 g, a bicycle has a mass of about 10 kg, a horse has a mass of about 750 kg.
During Guided Practice, students are solving word problems using the bar model.

objective: solve word problems involving multiplication of mass.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Ask them what 'twice as heavy' means. Allow them to discuss and show you using a bar model what this might look like. Can we show twice as heavy without knowing an actual mass? Is it possible using a bar model? Show students a container or box and ask them what they would expect if we had twice as many containers/boxes? What about double the amount? Is there a difference between twice as much and double?
Refer to Master. The yellow box weighs 17 kg and the green box is twice as heavy as the yellow box; can we draw a bar model to represent this problem? Let students use some paper strips to represent the bars. Ask them how long the paper strip representing the green box would be in relation to the paper strip representing the yellow box. If the yellow box weighs 17 kg, how can we work out what the green box weighs? How can we double 17 kg? We can use addition (17 + 17) or multiplication (17 × 2). 17 × 2 can be 10 × 2 + 7 × 2 = 20 + 14 = 34.
During Guided Practice, students are solving comparative word problems using bar models.

objective: solve word problems involving division of mass.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and discuss the problem with them. What key information is given? What do we need to know before we can find the solution? Gather students' opinions and ask them questions so that everyone can understand each others' thinking.
Refer to Master. How can we represent the problem using a bar model? Sam makes 3 meals and uses the same amount of rice for each one. He has 13 g of rice left. What can we do to show how he used the rice and how much he had left? We can draw a part–whole bar model to represent what he used and what was left. Altogether he had 100 g of rice; how much did he use for the 3 meals? How can we work this out? 100 – 13. So he must have used 87 g on the 3 meals as 87 g + 13 g gives us 100 g, which is the amount he began with. How can we work out how much rice he used for each meal? We can divide 87 by 3 since he used the same amount of rice for each. How can we easily divide 87 by 3? We can think of 87 as 60 and 27 and show this in a part-whole model. We know 60 divided by 3 is 20 and 27 divided by 3 is 9, therefore 87 ÷ 3 must be 20 + 9 = 29. So, Sam used 29 g of rice for each meal.
Remind students they can check the division calculation using multiplication.
During Guided Practice, students are using bar models to solve complex word problems. Encourage them to check and evaluate their approach to the problems.

relate the problem to appropriate operations for the calculation.
Students are able to use/draw a part–whole bar model to represent the problem.
Students are able to use/draw a comparison bar model to represent the problem.

objective: measure volume in millilitres.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Start by having two or three small, different sized/shaped containers of water. Ask the class which container has the most amount of water. Gather opinions and start to pour out the water from the containers into two or three identical glasses to show which container has the most liquid. Explain to the class that we can see clearly which container has more/less water than the other, but we still do not know how much water is in any of the containers.
Refer to Master: To measure the water we can use a special beaker with markings on the side. Ask students if they know what we call the measurement for liquid. Tell them your friend said it is the same as length: centimetres. Is this true? Tell them we call the amount of water in the container 'volume', and it can be measured by litres and millilitres, written as 'l' and 'ml'. Explain how to measure the volume of water in millilitres, including reading the scale on the beaker, and then measure the volume in your containers.
During Guided Practice, students are looking at how much liquid is in each container and recording the volume.
formative_assessment: use the term 'volume' to describe the amount of water in a container.

objective: measure capacity in millilitres.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Place a bottle or a glass with 250 ml of water on each table; this should be full capacity and have no markers on it. Ask students how they can measure the water in the bottle/glass. They should suggest pouring the water into a beaker which has markers on to measure the volume.
Refer to Master: Ask students how much water the bottle can hold. Explain that this is what is meant by the term 'capacity'. Capacity tells us how much liquid can be held in the bottle. If the water lands on a marker between 200 and 300, how can we work out how much water is in the beaker? The marker is halfway between 200 and 300 ml; what is halfway between 200 and 300?
During Guided Practice, students are looking at the volume of liquid in different beakers in millilitres.

objective: measure volume in millilitres and litres.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Give them time to discuss their methods. Ask them why this might be different from the explore task from yesterday.
Refer to Master 1: Ask them what is different about this beaker in comparison to the ones we have seen before. What does the number at the top mean? Above 900 is 1 l. What could that mean? Allow students to discuss this and what it means. Ask them to come up with some answers.
Refer to Master 2: Tell students that the smaller markers on the beaker indicate 50 ml because it is the midpoint of 100 ml. How much water can you see in the beaker?
Refer to Master 3: Explain that 1000ml would be the next marker on the beaker above 900ml, but this is equal to 1 litre. Show how to write l for litres and ml for millilitres.
During Guided Practice, students are looking at the amount of liquid in beakers in millilitres and litres.

objective: add and subtract volume.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task and allow them time to discuss.
Refer to Master 1: Two 500 ml beakers make 1000 ml. 500 ml + 500 ml = 1000 ml. This can be shown using a bar model. Draw the bar model to shadow the part–whole concept of making 1000 ml.
Are there any other ways of making 1000 ml? Explain to students that 1000 ml is equal to 1 l. Allow them to go through as many different ways to make 1 l as possible and share their findings. Essentially students have to make 1000 using different combinations of two numbers, multiples of 100 or multiples of 50.
Refer to Master 2: Ten 100 ml bottles of liquid is equal to 1,000 ml of liquid.
Refer to Master 3: How much more water is needed to make 1 l? Can we draw a bar model to show it? What calculation do we need to do to find the answer? Could we use a number bond to work out the answer?
During Guided Practice, students are finding volume and the difference required to make a volume.

approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Give out paper strips and ask the class to work in pairs using the strips to solve the problem. Gather the class together and ask students to show their solutions. Go through any misconceptions and errors that arise.
Refer to Master: Explain that we can use the paper strips to represent the problem or draw a bar model. Draw one bar to represent the amount of paint the painter used last month. What volume of paint did the painter use last month (132 l)? If the painter needs 27 l more this month, would the bar for this month be smaller or bigger than the bar for last month? If we draw an identical bar for this month, what would that mean? We are told that the painter needs 27 l more this month, so we can draw an extra portion for this month and extend the bar. What volume of paint does this 'extra' part of the bar represent (27 l)? We need to find out how much paint the painter needs this month. objective: solve multi-step word problems involving multiplication and division of volume.
approach:
To begin this lesson, show students the Explore task. Read the problem and ask them to use paper strips to represent the different parts in the question to help solve the problem.
After some time, gather the class and go through the solutions they come up with. Go through any misconceptions and errors.
Refer to Master: Draw a bar which represents how much shampoo was in the container before the 46 ml bottles were filled. Then ask the class how much was left in the container once the 6 bottles were filled. Draw a section on the bar model to represent how much was left.
Ask students: 1) What the second section of the bar represents; and 2) How we can work out the first section of the bar. We know there are 6 bottles, each with 46 ml of shampoo (draw 6 small bars representing the 6 bottles). What is the total volume of shampoo in the 6 bottles? What calculation do we need to use for this (46 × 6)? How can we do this (40 × 6) + (6 × 6)? This tells us how much shampoo was used in the 6 bottles. The question asks how much shampoo was in the bottle initially. What do we need to do to work that out? 276 ml + 550 ml = 826 ml.
